sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1:
Consider the following nonlinear equation: 

                    f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 = 0

Use the Newton-Raphson method to find the root of the equation correct to 4 decimal places. Use an initial guess of x0 = 2.5. Show all the iterations until the convergence.
message_2:
To apply the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x):

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

The Newton-Raphson formula is:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We will use the initial guess x0 = 2.5 and iterate until the difference between successive approximations is less than 0.0001 (4 decimal places).

Iteration 1:
x0 = 2.5
f(x0) = (2.5)^3 - 2(2.5) - 5 = 7.625
f'(x0) = 3(2.5)^2 - 2 = 16.5
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.5 - 7.625 / 16.5 = 2.0379

Iteration 2:
x0 = 2.0379
f(x0) = (2.0379)^3 - 2(2.0379) - 5 = 0.1558
f'(x0) = 3(2.0379)^2 - 2 = 10.4582
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.0379 - 0.1558 / 10.4582 = 2.0223

Iteration 3:
x0 = 2.0223
f(x0) = (2.0223)^3 - 2(2.0223) - 5 = 0.0056
f'(x0) = 3(2.0223)^2 - 2 = 10.2683
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.0223 - 0.0056 / 10.2683 = 2.0219

Iteration 4:
x0 = 2.0219
f(x0) = (2.0219)^3 - 2(2.0219) - 5 = 0.0001
f'(x0) = 3(2.0219)^2 - 2 = 10.2641
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.0219 - 0.0001 / 10.2641 = 2.0219

The difference between the last two approximations is less than 0.0001, so we can stop here. The root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 = 0, correct to 4 decimal places, is x = 2.0219.
